title: 107_hr4721
content: The Act is titled the "Lower Connecticut River Partnership Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Connecticut River watershed in Connecticut and Massachusetts is a scenic region with working farms, forests, and the Connecticut River. It provides habitat, recreation, and hydropower generation. Congress recognizes it as part of the Silvio O. Conte National Fish and Wildlife Refuge. The Connecticut River watershed in Connecticut and Massachusetts was designated as one of 14 American Heritage Rivers in 1998 due to citizen stewardship. The Act authorizes the Secretary to provide technical and financial assistance for management of the River and its watershed. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "River" as the Connecticut River, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, and "State" as either Connecticut or Massachusetts. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to States for managing the Connecticut River and its watershed, including developing policies for water quality, protection plans for tributaries, monitoring river quality, restoring riverbanks, and assisting communities and landowners. The Secretary may provide assistance for establishing riparian buffers, preventing pollution, protecting shoreland and wetland, managing stormwater runoff, evaluating dam decommissioning, restoring habitat, protecting native trout and wildlife, promoting local agricultural markets, and preserving farmland. Encouraging protection of farmland, sustainable agriculture, heritage trails, water trails, heritage tourism, agritourism, economic development, local stewardship, nonregulatory protection of heritage resources, public access to the River, indicators of sustainability, monitoring tourism impact on natural resources. Administrative costs limited to 10% of funds. The Act limits administrative costs to 10% of funds allocated to each State. States are encouraged to collaborate with local government and nonprofits for activities under the Act.
